THE WASHINGTON STATE RECREATION AND CONSERVATION OFFICE WILL SUBGRANT THE LWCF AWARD TO THE CITY OF UNIVERSITY PLACE TO RENOVATE AND EXPAND CIRQUE PARK  THE CURRENT SKATE PARK S WOODEN RAMPS WILL BE REPLACED WITH CONCRETE AND PAVE THE EXISTING GRAVEL WALKING PATH  ALONG WITH NINE NEW FITNESS STATIONS ALONG THE PATH AND A NEW PLAYGROUND  THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT A WIDER RANGE OF USERS AT THE PARK BY EXPANDING OPPORTUNITIES

THE WASHINGTON STATE RECREATION AND CONSERVATION OFFICE WILL SUBGRANT THE LWCF AWARD TO KING COUNTY TO ACQUIRE AND DEVELOP A 5 11 ACRE PROPERTY IN UNINCORPORATED KING COUNTY  THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO ESTABLISH A FORMAL PUBLIC ACCESS POINT FOR THE 155 ACRE LITTLE LAKE FOREST PARK, THUS PROVIDING ACCESS TO NATURE AND RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES  THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE COMMUNITY BY PROVIDING A PLACE FOR GATHERINGS IN A NATURAL SETTING IN CLOSE PROXIMITY TO THE CITY

THE WASHINGTON RECREATION AND CONSERVATION OFFICE WILL SUBGRANT THE LWCF AWARD TO THE CITY OF COVINGTON TO ACQUIRE AND DEVELOP A MAIN ENTRANE TO JENKINS CREEK PARK  THIS GRANT WILL ACQUIRE A 1 95 ACRE TARGET PARCEL TO CREATE A MAIN ENTRANCE FOR THE 22 13 ACRE JENKINS CREEK PARK AND DEVELOP IT WITH THE PARK S ONLY ON SITE PARKING, ENTRY SIGNAGE, TRAILHEAD KIOSK, TRASH RECEPTACLES, LIGHTING, ACCESS GATE, AND SITE FOR FUTURE RESTROOMS  IMPROVEMENTS PLANNED INCLUDE DEMOLITION REMOVAL OF STRUCTURES, GRADING, PEDESTRIAN IMPROVEMENTS  PATHWAYS, TRAILS , STREET FRONTAGE IMPROVEMENTS, STORMWATER MANAGEMENT IMPROVEMENTS, UTILITY IMPROVEMENTS, PARKING LOT  INCLUDING ADA PARKING SPACES, LIGHTING, SIGNAGE, GATE , AND SIGNAGE THE CITY OF COVINGTON WILL BENEFIT FROM IMPROVED ACCESS TO THE PARK ALLOWING FOR INCREASED OPPORTUNITY FOR PASSIVE RECREATION AND GREATER PHYSICAL AND MENTAL WELLNESS

21-01599 ABSTRACT SUMMARYTHE KENTUCKY DEPARTMENT FOR LOCAL GOVERNMENT OFFICE OF FEDERAL GRANTS WILL SUBGRANT THE LWCF AWARD TO FLOYD COUNTY FISCAL COURT TO TO CONSTRUCT A 20' X 30' SHELTER WITH INSTALLED PICNIC TABLES, AND AN ADA COMPLIANT PLAYGROUND AT MELVIN PARK LOCATED IN MELVIN, KENTUCKY. A SIDEWALK FROM THE PARKING AREA TO THE SHELTER, BUILDING AND PLAYGROUND WILL BE POURED TO ACCOMMODATE WHEELCHAIRS AND MAKE WALKING EASIER. GENERAL SITE IMPROVEMENTS INCLUDE SITE PREPARATION, GRADING, LANDSCAPING, INSTALLATION OF THE PLAYGROUND, CONSTRUCTION OF THE PICNIC SHELTER AND CONSTRUCTION OF THE PARKING FACILITIES AND SIDEWALKS. THE OUTCOME WILL RESULT IN ACCESS TO RECREATIONAL ACTIVITIES TO PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES AND IMPROVED SAFETY WITHIN THE PARK.

21-01603 ABSTRACT SUMMARYTHE KENTUCKY DEPARTMENT FOR LOCAL GOVERNMENT OFFICE OF FEDERAL GRANTS WILL SUBGRANT THE LWCF AWARD TO THE CITY OF ELIZABETHTOWN TO REPLACE THE PLAYGROUND LOCATED AT FREEMAN LAKE PARK. THE OLD PLAYGROUND WILL BE REPLACED WITH A METAL/PLASTIC COMPOSITE STRUCTURE FEATURING VARIOUS PLAY COMPONENTS, POURED-IN-PLACE SURFACE PATHWAYS, AND ACCESSIBLE RAMPS AND PLATFORMS. THE NEW PLAYGROUND WILL BE RELOCATED IN THE FORMER SAND VOLLEYBALL COURT AREA NOT FAR FROM THE OLD PLAYGROUND SITE. THE OUTCOME WILL RESULT IN IMPROVED AMENITIES AND SAFETY FOR PARK VISITORS.

21-01602 ABSTRACT SUMMARYTHE KENTUCKY DEPARTMENT FOR LOCAL GOVERNMENT OFFICE OF FEDERAL GRANTS WILL SUBGRANT THE LWCF AWARD TO CARROLL COUNTY FISCAL COURT TO RESURFACE THE EXISTING ADA NATURE TRAIL AT THE CAMP KYSOC FACILITIES. THE CURRENT TRAIL NETWORK CONTAINS OVER 2 MILES OF TRAIL. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED UNDER THE PROJECT SCOPE OF WORK INCLUDE PREPPING TRAILS (SWEEP/CLEAN/MILL) WHERE NECESSARY AND PAVING WITH A CL2 ASPHALT SURFACE 1' THICK. THE TRAIL NETWORK AND PARK FACILITIES WERE BUILT IN 1961 AS PART OF A RESIDENT AND RESPITE FACILITY OPERATED BY EASTER SEALS THAT PROVIDED CHILDREN AND ADULTS WITH DISABILITIES THE OPPORTUNITY TO ENJOY THE WONDERS OF THE OUTDOORS IN A SAFE AND FUN ENVIRONMENT. THE OUTCOME OF THIS PROJECT WILL RESURFACE THE TRAIL TO PROVIDE HIKING AND HORSE-RIDING RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITY TO CHILDREN AND ADULTS WITH DISABILITIES.

THE KENTUCKY DEPARTMENT FOR LOCAL GOVERNMENT OFFICE OF FEDERAL GRANTS WILL SUBGRANT THE LWCF AWARD TO THE CITY OF HORSE CAVE TO CONSTRUCT A NEW CITY PARK OVER SUNSET DOME. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE DEVELOPING A WALKING PATH, ADDING PARKING SPACES, WOOD BENCHES, SIGNAGE, PICNIC TABLES, TWO GAZEBOS, AND TRASH RECEPTACLES. THE OUTCOME WILL RESULT IN IMPROVEMENTS TO RECREATIONAL AMENITIES WITHIN THE PARK AND NEW PARK FEATURES.

21-01600 ABSTRACT SUMMARYTHE KENTUCKY DEPARTMENT FOR LOCAL GOVERNMENT OFFICE OF FEDERAL GRANTS WILL SUBGRANT THE LWCF AWARD TO THE CITY OF MIDDLETOWN TO FURTHER DEVELOP WETHERBY PARK. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE CONSTRUCTING A 20 SQ. FT. PICNIC SHELTER WITH A METAL ROOF ON A 24X24 CONCRETE PAD, PURCHASING AND INSTALLING FOUR ADA COMPLIANT PICNIC TABLES, FOUR TRASH RECEPTACLES, AND THREE 6' BENCHES WITH BACKS. PROJECT ALSO INCLUDES LIGHTING, SIGNAGE, AND LANDSCAPING. THE OUTCOME WILL RESULT IN ACCESS TO RECREATIONAL AMENITIES FOR PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES AND NEW FEATURES WITHIN THE PARK.

21-01604 ABSTRACT SUMMARYTHE KENTUCKY DEPARTMENT FOR LOCAL GOVERNMENT OFFICE OF FEDERAL GRANTS WILL SUBGRANT THE LWCF AWARD TO LIVINGSTON COUNTY FISCAL COURT CONSTRUCT A NEW COMMUNITY PARK IN THE CITY OF LEDBETTER. THE NEW PARK WILL FEATURE A BASKETBALL COURT, PLAYGROUND WITH SWING SET, PICNIC SHELTER, AND 1/8 MILE ASPHALT WALKING TRAIL. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO INCLUDE VARIOUS SITE AMENITIES, SUCH AS TRASH RECEPTACLES, BENCHES, PICNIC TABLES, LIGHTING, LANDSCAPING, AND A SECURITY SYSTEM. THE OUTCOME WILL RESULT IN IMPROVED AMENITIES AND RECREATIONAL FEATURES AT THE PARK.

THE CITY OF WILLCOX, THROUGH ARIZONA STATE PARKS AND TRIALS, WILL UTILIZE A LAND AND WATER CONSERVATION FUND GRANT TO FURTHER RENOVATE/DEVELOP KEILLER PARK AND THE QUAIL DRIVE SPORTS PARK.RENOVATIONS TO KEILLER PARK WILL REPLACE PLAYGROUND EQUIPMENT, REPLACE A CANOPY COVER, CONVERT THE THREE BALLFIELDS TO LED LIGHTING, UPGRADE RESTROOM FACILITIES, UPGRADE THE SPRINKLER SYSTEM, REPLACE BALL FIELD FENCING, AND REPLACE EXISTING SWIMMING POOL. NEW DEVELOPMENT INCLUDES INSTALLATION OF A SPLASH PARK AND PARK WORKOUT EQUIPMENT. THE RENOVATIONS WILL RESULT IN MAJOR ENERGY AND WATER EFFICIENCY IMPROVEMENTS THAT WILL SAVE THE CITY SIGNIFICANT COSTS.RENOVATIONS AT QUAIL PARK PROJECT WILL COVERT MULTIUSE FIELD WITH LED LIGHTING, ADD GOAL POSTS, REPLACE PLAYGROUND CANOPY COVER, UPGRADE RESTROOMS, AND REPLACE MULTIUSE FENCING. NEW DEVELOPMENT WILL CONSTRUCT A COVERED RODEO ARENA. A LIGHT-COLORED ROOF COVER ON ARENA WILL REFLECT HEAT AND WILL REDUCE AMOUNT OF WATER NEEDED TO BE PLACED ON THE ARENA TO CONTROL DUST. CAPTURE AND/OR REDIRECTION OF RAINWATER FROM THE COVERED ARENA CAN HELP REDUCE THE USE OF POTABLE WATER TO CREATE SUSTAINABLE LANDSCAPES AND BEAUTIFY QUAIL PARK

THE ARIZONA STATE PARKS AND TRAILS WILL SUBGRANT THE LWCF AWARD TO THE THE CITY OF SIERRA VISTA, TO FURTHER RENOVATE/DEVELOP VETERAN'S MEMORIAL PARK. DEVELOPMENT INCLUDES ELECTRICAL UPGRADES, A 150,000 GALLON STORAGE TANK, NEW ONSITE PIPING, FENCING, AND A BOOSTER STATION HOUSED IN A METAL BUILDING. RENOVATION FOR THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE IRRIGATION REPLACEMENT AND INSTALLATION OF ARTIFICIAL TURF. THESE IMPROVEMENTS WILL ALLOW FOR USAGE FOR THE PUBLIC REGARDLESS OF RACE, SEXUAL ORIENTATION, SOCIO-ECONOMIC STATUS, AND FOR ALL AGES AND ABILITY LEVELS.

THE WASHINGTON STATE RECREATION AND CONSERVATION OFFICE WILL SUBGRANT THE LWCF AWARD TO THE CITY OF POULSBO TO DEVELOP AN INCLUSIVE PLAYGROUND IN RAAB PARK NEXT TO THE EXISTING SMALL ACCESSIBLE PLAYGROUND THAT IS NOT FULLY INCLUSIVE  NO PLAY EQUIPMENT WILL BE REMOVED, BUT 7 NEW PIECES OF EQUIPMENT AND NUMEROUS SENSORY STATIONS WILL BE ADDED, ALL OF WHICH ARE DESIGNED TO ACCOMMODATE PHYSICAL DISABILITIES AND PROVIDE A SENSORY RICH EXPERIENCE  THE 9,000 SF PLAYGROUND FOOTPRINT WILL FEATURE A SOFT, PADDED SYNTHETIC SURFACE AND WHEELCHAIR ACCESSIBLE RAMPS  THE NEW EQUIPMENT WILL INCLUDE SPECIALLY DESIGNED PIECES SUCH AS A WHEELCHAIR FRIENDLY MERRY GO ROUND, INCLUSIVE TEETER TOTTER, EXTRA WIDE SLIDES, AND SWING SEATS THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE FASTEST GROWING CITY IN KITSAP COUNTY, WHICH WILL ONLY CONTINUE AS RESIDENTIAL GROWTH IS GROWING, WHERE OVER 500 NEW HOMES ARE IN PROCESS  POPULATION NUMBERS BY 2030 EXPECT TO HIT AN ADDITIONAL 20   THIS PROJECT WILL SERVE YOUTH, ADULTS AND FAMILIES WHO WANT TO RECREATE SAFELY  AND WILL ALSO SERVE THE OVER 65 POPULATION WHO WANT TO ACCESS THESE KINDS OF ACTIVITIES WITH THEIR GRANDCHILDREN

THE WASHINGTON STATE RECREATION AND CONSERVATION OFFICE WILL SUBGRANT THE LWCF AWARD TO THE CITY OF OTHELLO TO DEVELOP  PRIDE ROCK PLAYGROUND , BY RENOVATING AND REPLACING AN EXISTING RECREATIONAL SITE AT LIONS PARK  COMPRISING NEARLY ONE ACRE, THE PROJECT WILL REPLACE UNSAFE 1950 S ERA PLAYGROUND EQUIPMENT AND HARD PACKED GRAVEL SURFACING AND BE REDESIGNED FOR INCLUSION AND EFFICIENCY, WITH LANDSCAPING AND FURNISHINGS THAT OFFER SHADE AND COMFORT  SPECIFIC REPLACEMENTS WILL INCLUDE INSTALLATION OF  ACCESSIBLE AND SAFE PLAYGROUND EQUIPMENT  RUBBER POURED IN PLACE SURFACING  PICNIC AREAS  WALKING PATHS  OPEN LAWN SPACE  IRRIGATION  AND TREES  THE PROJECT WILL DIRECTLY BENEFIT OTHELLO S LARGE, UNDERSERVED YOUTH POPULATION, 35 PERCENT OF WHOM LIVE IN POVERTY  THE PRIMARY RECREATIONAL USE WILL BE BY CHILDREN 12 YEARS OLD AND UNDER, ACCOMPANIED BY THEIR FAMILIES, TEACHERS AND DAY CARE PROVIDERS

THE IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF PARKS AND RECREATION WILL SUBGRANT THE LWCF AWARD TO CITY OF HAYDEN TO DEVELOP THE 37-ACRE CROFFOOT PARK. NEW DEVELOPMENT WILL INCLUDE A RESTROOM/CONCESSION FACILITY, PICNIC SHELTER, ADDITIONAL PARKING LOT SOUTH OF THE EXISTING PARKING LOT, PROVIDE ELECTRICAL HOOKUPS AND PARKING PADS FOR 2 FOOD TRUCK LOCATIONS, 6 VARYING SIZE SOCCER FIELDS, IRRIGATION, LANDSCAPING, WINDBREAKS, AND INCLUSIVE AND ACCESSIBLE PEDESTRIAN PATH CONNECTIVITY. THE PROJECT WILL ENHANCE THE EXISTING CROFFOOT PARK WHICH EXPANDS THE "CLOSE-TO-HOME" RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR RESIDENTS AND OTHERS WHO VISIT THE PARK FOR BASEBALL OR SOCCER TOURNAMENTS. THE PATHS, SHELTER, AND CONCESSION/RESTROOM FACILITY WILL ALL BE BUILT TO INCLUSIVE AND ACCESSIBLE STANDARDS TO PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR PEOPLE OF ALL ABILITIES TO ENJOY THE PARK.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF PARKS AND RECREATION WILL SUBGRANT THE LWCF AWARD TO THE CITY OF SAN MATEO TO INSTALL A SCHOOL-AGED PLAYGROUND AND A TOT PLAYGROUND, BOTH WITH SAFETY SURFACING AND ACCESSIBLE RAMPS, FENCING, SHADE STRUCTURES, BENCHES, PICNIC TABLES, LIGHTING, TRASH AND RECYCLING RECEPTACLES, DRINKING FOUNTAIN, BIKE RACKS, SIGNAGE, OPEN SPACE AREA, ACCESSIBLE PATHWAYS THROUGH THE PARK AND LANDSCAPING WITHIN BOREL PARK. THE OUTCOME OF THE PROJECT IN AN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITY WILL PROVIDE INCREASED PUBLIC OUTDOOR RECREATION OPPORTUNITIES TO SUPPORT HEALTHY LIFESTYLES AND ACCESS TO SAFE, COMMUNITY-BUILDING RECREATION. THE NEAREST OPPORTUNITY SIMILAR TO THIS IS A HALF MILE AWAY.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF PARKS AND RECREATION WILL SUBGRANT THE LWCF AWARD TO THE CITY OF PALM SPRINGS TO RENOVATE AND EXPAND THE DEMUTH PARK  THE PROJECT WILL RENOVATE THE AREA CURRENTLY USED AS A DOG PARK INTO A 1 6 ACRE LARGE DOG PARK AREA  CONSTRUCT A NEW  35 ACRE DOG PARK FOR SMALL DOGS  AND, ENLARGE AND PAVE THE PARKING LOT  OTHER IMPROVEMENTS INCLUDE THE INSTALLATION OF SHADE STRUCTURES, TRASH AND WASTE STATIONS, PERIMETER FENCING WITH ENTRY, LIGHTING, BENCHES, DRINKING FOUNTAINS AND LANDSCAPING  THE OUTCOME OF THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE AN UNMET NEED IN THE CITY  DEMUTH PARK IS ONE OF THE MOST UTILIZED PARKS IN THE CITY  RESIDENTS, MANY OF WHOM ARE LOW INCOME FAMILIES AND SENIORS, HAVE BEEN REQUESTING THIS PARK AMENITY FOR MANY YEARS, AS IT IS DIFFICULT TO TRAVEL TO THE ONLY ESTABLISHED DOG PARK IN THE CITY, WHICH IS EXTREMELY OVERCROWDED

THE MASSACHUSETTS EXECUTIVE OFFICE OF ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENTAL AFFAIRS WILL SUBGRANT THE LWCF AWARD TO THE MASSACHUSETTS DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME (DFG) TO ACQUIRE AND PROTECT 186 ACRES OF LAND WITH EXISTING TRAILS, INCLUDING THE SOUTH PEAK OF MOUNT WATATIC WHICH DIRECTLY ABUTS THE 281.5-ACRE MOUNT WATATIC RESERVATION. THIS AREA WAS PROTECTED WITH A PREVIOUS LWCF GRANT (25-00458). THE PROPERTY IS CENTRALLY LOCATED WITHIN AN EXTENSIVE LANDSCAPE OF CONSERVATION LAND THAT WILL BE ACCESSIBLE TO THE PUBLIC FOR HIKING, FISHING, HUNTING, WILDLIFE OBSERVATION, AND ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION IMMEDIATELY FOLLOWING ACQUISITION. THE NORTH COUNTY LAND TRUST IS THE PROPERTY OWNER. A SMALL INFORMATION KIOSK AND BOUNDARY SIGNS PLACED WITHIN TWO MONTHS OF ACQUISITION.THE ACQUISITION WILL HELP INCREASE FACILITY LONGEVITY BY PROVIDING ADDITIONAL RECREATIONAL RESOURCES TO AN ABUTTING LWCF SITE IN AN AREA OF THE STATE THAT'S POPULATION IS INCREASING. ACQUISITION OF THIS PARCEL WILL ALLOW THE PUBLIC ACCESS TO TRAILS AND UNDEVELOPED HABITAT TO UTILIZE FOR PASSIVE RECREATIONAL ACTIVITIES INCLUDING HUNTING, FISHING, BIRDWATCHING, CROSS-COUNTRY SKIING, AND HIKING. THE PROPERTY CONNECTS TO EXISTING TRAILS AND CONSERVATION LAND.

THE MASSACHUSETTS EXECUTIVE OFFICE OF ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENTAL AFFAIRS WILL SUBGRANT THE LWCF AWARD TO THE TOWN OF WESTPORT WILL ACQUIRE A CONSERVATION EASEMENT FROM BUZZARDS BAY COALITION (BBC) TO PROTECT 25.65 ACRES OF LAND AND PROVIDE EXCEPTIONAL RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES, INCLUDING HIKING, FISHING, HUNTING, NATURE OBSERVATION, AND ENVIRONMENTAL ED; PROTECT IMPORTANT WATER AND FISHERIES HABITAT; AND EXPAND AN EXISTING GREENWAY ALONG ANGELINE BROOK.THE CURRENT PROPERTY OWNER IS CARRICORP INDUSTRIES. BBC WILL ACQUIRE THE PROPERTY FEE SIMPLE FROM CARRICORP INDUSTRIES USING LWCF ASSISTANCE. THE WHOLE PROPERTY IS FORESTED AND CONTAINS SOME 650 LINEAR FEET OF ANGELINE BROOK ALONG WITH SOME SEVEN ACRES OF MASSACHUSETTS DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION-MAPPED CORE WETLAND RESOURCES. BBC PLANS TO FORMALIZE SIGNAGE AND THE EXISTING TRAIL NETWORK CONNECTING TO TRAILS ON ABUTTING CONSERVATION LAND AND IN THE FUTURE IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE TOWN, BBC MAY ESTABLISH A TRAILHEAD, AND, POTENTIALLY, A PARKING AREA TO ENHANCE PUBLIC ACCESS.THE LWCF GRANT WILL ENABLE ACRES OF FOREST TO BECOME PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE VIA WALKING/HIKING TRAILS AND ENABLE ACCESS TO ANGELINE BROOK. THE LAND ACQUISITION WILL HELP PROTECT SEA RUN EASTERN BROOK TROUT AND WATER-DEPENDENT BIRD HABITAT. IT IS IMPORTANT FROM A CLIMATE CHANGE RESILIENCY STANDPOINT. IT WILL PROVIDE IMPORTANT RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES, SUCH AS HIKING AND FISHING. THE PROPERTY IS PART OF A LARGER VISION TO CONNECT NEIGHBORHOODS TO THE VILLAGE CENTER.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF PARKS AND RECREATION WILL SUBGRANT THE LWCF AWARD TO THE CITY OF ANAHEIM TO RENOVATE AND EXPAND CENTER GREENS PARK. THE CITY PLANS TO RENOVATE THE EXISTING BASKETBALL COURT; DEVELOP A NEW SKATE PARK, YOUTH CHALLENGE COURSE, TOT LOT, FITNESS LOOP TRAIL, SHADED SITTING/PICNIC PLAZA AND BUTTERFLY GARDEN; INSTALL CONCRETE WALKWAYS, BENCHES, DRINKING FOUNTAINS, BIKE RACKS, TRASH RECEPTACLES, LIGHTING, SIGNAGE AND FENCING; AND, LANDSCAPE. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN NEW AND DIVERSE RECREATION AMENITIES WHERE VERY LITTLE EXISTS CURRENTLY. INCREASED OPPORTUNITIES TO RECREATE WILL PROVIDE HEALTH BENEFITS TO A COMMUNITY WITH VERY HIGH RATES OF CHILD OBESITY AND ASTHMA.

THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF PARKS AND RECREATION WILL SUBGRANT THE LWCF AWARD TO THE CITY OF BELL GARDENS TO REPLACE THE EXISTING NON OPERABLE POOL AT JOHN ANSON FORD PARK WITH A NEW COMPETITION SIZED POOL, AN ACTIVITY POOL, AND A THERAPEUTIC POOL  ALL THREE WILL BE ACCESSIBLE  ADDITIONALLY, AN EXISTING BUILDING WILL BE RENOVATED INTO A CHANGING FACILITY WITH RESTROOMS AND SHOWERS  THE NEW REGIONAL AQUATIC CENTER COMPLEX WILL ALSO BE IMPROVED WITH A SLIDE, PERMANENT BLEACHERS, SHADE CANOPIES, FENCING AND LANDSCAPING  THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT A DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITY  MORE THAN 12,000 RESIDENTS LIVE WITHIN A HALF MILE OF THIS FACILITY  CHILDREN, SENIORS AND AT RISK YOUTH ARE PARTICULARLY EXPECTED TO BENEFIT FROM THE OPPORTUNITY TO TAKE SWIM LESSONS, AQUATIC BASED FITNESS CLASSES, AND ENGAGE IN OTHER WATER BASED RECREATION ACTIVITIES

THE MASSACHUSETTS EXECUTIVE OFFICE OF ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENTAL AFFAIRS WILL SUBGRANT THE LWCF AWARD TO THE CITY OF LAWRENCE (CITY) WILL DEMOLISH THE EXISTING NON-COMPLIANT PLAYGROUND AND BUILD A NEW FULLY ACCESSIBLE PLAYGROUND WITH WATER SPRAY FEATURES, RENOVATE THE BANDSTAND GAZEBO TO MAKE IT ACCESSIBLE INCLUDING A LAND BRIDGE AND A RETAINING WALL, SITE PREPARATION, ACCESSIBLE ROUTES, UTILITIES, AND LANDSCAPING.THE SITE DESIGN INCLUDES THE PLANTING OF 20 TREES. THE PARK IS LOCATED IN THE TOP QUARTILE FOR URBAN HEAT ISLAND IN THE STATE.. THIS PROJECT WILL CREATE A DESTINATION FOR PLAY AND COMMUNITY BUILDING. THE CURRENT CONCEPT DRAWS ON SEVERAL UNIVERSAL DESIGN PRINCIPALS THAT GO BEYOND FOLLOWING ADA GUIDELINES TO MAKE THE SPACE ACCESSIBLE FOR THOSE WITH VISIBLE AS WELL AS INVISIBLE DISABILITIES. TO ENSURE EVERYONE HAS AN EQUAL OPPORTUNITY TO PARTICIPATE DESIGN THE PLAYGROUND WILL NOT SEGREGATE THE PLAY EXPERIENCE. THE DESIGN WILL PROVIDE PERCEPTIBLE INFORMATION TO APPEAL TO MANY SENSES (VISUAL, AUDITORY, TACTILE, EXPERIENTIAL, ETC.). EQUIPMENT SPECIFIED WILL HAVE A TOLERANCE FOR ERROR MEANING THE USER CAN TRY SOMETHING AND FAIL SAFELY WHILE STILL BEING CHALLENGED. THE PROPOSED SIZE AND LAYOUT OF THE SPACE CREATES SIMPLE AND INTUITIVE PLAY OPPORTUNITIES FOR A WIDE VARIETY OF BODY TYPES, SIZES, AGES, AND ABILITIES.

THE MASSACHUSETTS EXECUTIVE OFFICE OF ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENTAL AFFAIRS WILL SUBGRANT THE LWCF AWARD TO THE TOWN OF DEERFIELD (TOWN) WILL DEVELOP AN ACCESS ROADWAY, BASKETBALL COURT, LARGE HANDICAP ACCESSIBLE PARKING LOT, ONE SMALL MULTI-PURPOSE ATHLETIC FIELD, ONE LARGE REGULATION-SIZED MULTI-PURPOSE COMPETITION ATHLETIC FIELD, A PAVED ACCESSIBLE PATH CONNECTING ALL WITH NATURE, NATURE VIEWING STATIONS, PLAYGROUND AREA, AND SITE FURNISHING AT NORTH MAIN STREET PARK. CLIMATE RESILIENCE HAS BEEN INCORPORATED INTO THE PARK DESIGN, INCLUDING PERMEABLE PAVEMENT, DEALING WITH STORMWATER ONSITE, INCLUDING THROUGH THE INSTALLATION OF RAIN GARDENS, AND THE PLANTING OF AT LEAST 24 TREES.THE TOWN HAS NOT COMPLETED A LWCF PROJECT IN THE RECENT PAST. THE SITE IS CENTRALLY LOCATED IN THE TOWN AND IS NEAR A SCHOOL PROVIDING GOOD ACCESS TO MULTIPLE USER GROUPS. TWO NON-PROFIT SCHOOL WILL DONATE A PAVILION (EAGLEBROOK SCHOOL), A LARGE STORAGE BUILDING THAT WILL TRIPLE AS RESTROOMS & CONCESSION STAND (DEERFIELD ACADEMY), AND NOW TREE HOUSE BREWING COMPANY WILL BE DONATING A BANDSHELL FOR OUTDOOR CONCERTS.

THE MASSACHUSETTS EXECUTIVE OFFICE OF ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENTAL AFFAIRS WILL SUBGRANT THE LWCF AWARD TO THE CITY OF SPRINGFIELD (CITY). THE CITY WILL MITIGATE HEAT ISLAND EFFECTS WITH TREE PLANTINGS AND A NEW SPLASH PAD, POLLINATOR GARDENS, BIOSWALES, NATURE-BASED STORMWATER TREATMENT SOLUTIONS, CULVERT REPLACEMENTS, AND TRAIL SYSTEM, ALONG WITH THE ADDITION OF 24.07 ACRES OF NEW PARKLAND. THE PROJECT WILL DEVELOP 19.184 ACRES OF EXISTING PARKLAND AND AN ADJACENT PARCEL OF 24.07 ACRES, WILL BE ADDED TO THE CITY OF SPRINGFIELD'S PARK LAND INVENTORY. THE PARCEL ADJACENT TO GREENLEAF PARK, BEHIND MARY A. WALSH ELEMENTARY SCHOOL, IS CURRENTLY CLASSIFIED AS SCHOOL DEPARTMENT PROPERTY AND THROUGH THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THIS GRANT PROJECT, THE PARCEL WILL BE DONATED/TRANSFERRED TO THE DEPARTMENT OF PARKS, BUILDINGS & RECREATION MANAGEMENT (PBRM) TO BE MAINTAINED AS A PUBLIC PARK UNDER MASSACHUSETTS GENERAL LAW CHAPTER 45, SECTION 14.THE CITY HAS RECEIVED TWO PREVIOUS LWCF DEVELOPMENT GRANTS FOR GREENLEAF PARK.. THE COMMUNITY CENTER WAS ACKNOWLEDGED AS EXISTING BY NPS AT THE TIME THE PROJECTS WERE APPROVED IN 1973 AND 1983, RESPECTIVELY, BUT A PUBLIC FACILITY REQUEST WAS NEVER SUBMITTED TO NPS. THE CITY HAS SUBMITTED THIS NEW DEVELOPMENT GRANT WHICH INCLUDES THE SCHOOL DISTRICT TRANSFERRING OWNERSHIP TO THE CITY OF SPRINGFIELD UNDER MASSACHUSETTS GENERAL LAW CHAPTER 45, SECTION 14. ON JANUARY 26, 2022, NPS APPROVED THE "PUBLIC FACILITY" ACCORDING TO THE CURRENT LWCF MANUAL VERSION 71 TO ENSURE THAT THE COMMUNITY CENTER IS AN ALLOWABLE USE AND SECONDARY TO PUBLIC OUTDOOR RECREATION.

THE MASSACHUSETTS EXECUTIVE OFFICE OF ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENTAL AFFAIRS WILL SUBGRANT THE LWCF AWARD TO THE CITY OF SOMERVILLE (CITY) WILL CONDUCT SITE PREPARATION, DEMOLISH AND REBUILD THE EXISTING SPLASH PAD, CONCRETE RETAINING WALL, AND BALLFIELDS' FENCING, BACKSTOPS, DUGOUTS, AND LIGHTING, AND ADD SHADE STRUCTURES TO THE BALLFIELDS, REBUILT/EXPAND THE SPLASH PAD/WATER PLAY AREA, RENOVATE THE PLAYGROUND BY ADDING NEW EQUIPMENT AND GROUND SURFACING, RESURFACING THE BASKETBALL COURTS, INSTALLING SITE AMENITIES, IMPROVING DRAINAGE AND LANDSCAPING AT CONWAY PARK.LWCF FUNDS WILL ALSO BE USED TO SURROUND THE NEW SPLASHPAD WITH POLLINATOR VEGETATION, REPLACE 48 TREES THAT MUST BE REMOVED DURING CLEANUP WITH 64 NEW SHADE TREES, CREATE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION SIGNAGE THAT ADDRESSES THE SITE'S HISTORY AND NEW POLLINATOR AND STORMWATER CONTROL ELEMENTS, AND PROVIDE FOR SOLAR TRASH COLLECTION AND RECYCLING.

THE MASSACHUSETTS EXECUTIVE OFFICE OF ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENTAL AFFAIRS WILL SUBGRANT THE LWCF AWARD TO THE CITY OF SALEM (CITY) WILL DEMOLISH THE EXISTING POOL, DEVELOP TWO NEW PUBLIC POOLS (ADULT/LAP & KIDDIE) TO SERVE DIFFERENT AGES AND ABILITIES, CREATING A CENTER FOR SWIMMING LESSONS, A PLACE TO COOL OFF, AND WATER SAFETY TRAINING; THE EXTENSION OF THE PARK'S WATERFRONT TRAIL WILL PROVIDE A CONTINUOUS PERIMETER PATH ALONG THE WATERFRONT AND ACCESS TO THE NEWLY RESTORED COVE (CURRENT ACCESS IS CUT OFF BY THE POOL); THE REHABILITATION OF THE EXISTING HISTORIC BATHHOUSE FOR FULLY ACCESSIBLE RECREATIONAL USE; THE CREATION OF A NATURE CLASSROOM ADDITION TO THE BATHHOUSE AS A LOCUS FOR ENVIRONMENTAL AND OUTDOOR RECREATION EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING; AND THE CREATION OF NEW LAWN AND LANDSCAPED AREAS FOR ACTIVE AND PASSIVE RECREATION.THE CITY HAS NOT RECENTLY RECEIVED A LWCF GRANT. THE CITY IS A REGULAR RECIPIENT OF THE STATE FUNDED PARK GRANT PROGRAM AND HAS SUCCESSFULLY COMPLETED MULTIPLE PARK RENOVATION PROJECTS IN RECENT YEARS. THE PROJECT WAS INSTIGATED DUE TO COASTAL FLOODING AND INUNDATION OF THE POOL. THE POOL HAS BEEN MOVED BACK FROM THE SHORELINE TO PREVENT FUTURE FLOODING. THE SPRAY PARK WILL SERVE AS A COOLING CENTER FOR RESIDENTS AS HOT SUMMER DAYS INCREASE IN THE FUTURE. THE RETURN OF THE TIDAL AREA WILL HELP WITH COASTAL RESILIENCE AS WELL. THE CITY'S PARK AND RECREATION DEPARTMENT IS PARTNERING WITH THE DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS ON MAINTENANCE.

THE MASSACHUSETTS EXECUTIVE OFFICE OF ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENTAL AFFAIRS WILL SUBGRANT THE LWCF AWARD TO THE CITY OF NEWBURYPORT (CITY) TO RESTORE BARTLET MALL PARK'S NORTHWEST CORNER. THE CITY WILL REPLACE THE EXISTING PLAYGROUND WITH A NEW ALL-INCLUSIVE PLAYGROUND AND AREA, RENOVATING THE BASKETBALL COURT, COMPLETING IMPROVEMENTS OF THE NORTHWEST SLOPE OF THE PARK TO IMPROVE ITS PASSIVE RECREATIONAL USEFULNESS AND IMPROVE WATER QUALITY OF THE FROG POND, ADD THE ORIGINALLY-INTENDED DRIVEWAY ENTRANCE FROM AUBURN STREET INTO THE PARK TO THE FROG POND, EXTEND THE PARK'S HIGH STREET PEDESTRIAN PROMENADE TO AUBURN STREET, AND PLANTING FOUR NEW TREES.THE CITY HAS NOT RECENTLY RECEIVED A LWCF GRANT, BUT ARE ACCOMPLISHED WITH ADMINISTERING OTHER FEDERAL GRANTS, AS WELL AS STATE FUNDED GRANTS. THE CITY PLANS TO PLANT FOUR TREES, ADD GREENSPACE, REDUCE IMPERVIOUS SURFACE BY 65%, WHICH WILL HELP REDUCE THE AMOUNT OF RUNOFF INTO THE POND AND HELP WITH RESILIENCY EFFORTS. THE NEWBURYPORT PARKS COMMISSION HAS DEVELOPMENT A MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR THE SITE, LEADING TO FACILITY LONGEVITY.

THE MASSACHUSETTS EXECUTIVE OFFICE OF ENERGY AND ENVIRONMENTAL AFFAIRS WILL SUBGRANT THE LWCF AWARD TO THE CITY OF HOLYOKE TO ACQUIRE 14.1 ACRES OF MATURE UPLAND OAK FOREST WITH A SHORT EXISTING TRAIL AT THE TOP OF ANNIVERSARY HILL TO HELP RETURN THE AREA TO ITS PROMINENCE AND PASSIVE RECREATION USE AS A POPULAR PICNIC SPOT AND COMMUNITY EVENTS AREA. THE PARCEL IS OWNED BY THE KESTREL LAND TRUST AND HAS AN EXISTING TRAIL USED BY THE PUBLIC.THE LAND WAS HISTORICALLY USED AS PART OF THE ADJACENT ANNIVERSARY HILL PARK, OWNED BY THE CITY OF HOLYOKE. CULTURAL RESOURCES NEARBY INCLUDE A STONEWORK BRIDGE AND CULVERT CONSTRUCTED BY THE CIVILIAN CONSERVATION CORPS IN 1939 AS PART OF THE IMPROVEMENT PROJECTS AT THE ADJACENT ANNIVERSARY HILL PARK. THE AREA THAT THE PARCEL IS IN IS MAPPED IN THE TOP QUARTILE FOR URBAN HEAT ISLAND EFFECT. BY ACQUIRING THIS LAND AND MAINTAINING IT AS OPEN SPACE, THE CLIMATE WILL BENEFIT. THE PARCEL IS ALSO THE HEADWATERS OF DAY BROOK. ITS PROTECTION WILL BENEFIT THE HEALTH OF THE STREAM, AS WELL AS PREVENTING FLOODING.

THE COLORADO DEPARTMENT OF PARKS AND WILDLIFE (CPW) WILL BE THE DIRECT RECIPIENT OF THIS LWCF REWARD TO UPDATE THEIR STATEWIDE COMPREHENSIVE OUTDOOR RECREATION PLAN (SCORP). THE SCORP WILL BUILD OFF COLORADO'S 2019-2023 SCORP PRIORITY AREAS AND BE USED TO GUIDE LWCF APPROPRIATIONS BY IDENTIFYING THE STATE'S MOST PRESSING OUTDOOR RECREATION ISSUES AND OPPORTUNITIES. THE OVERALL APPROACH BUILDS ON COLORADO'S 2019 SCORP, WITH RESEARCH INTO OUTDOOR RECREATION TRENDS AND PARTICIPATION, AN ASSESSMENT OF ECONOMIC CONTRIBUTIONS, AND STAKEHOLDER INVOLVEMENT. WITH THIS PROCESS, CPW WILL ALSO INCORPORATE AN INNOVATIVE APPROACH TO ENGAGING LOCAL AND REGIONAL VOICES THROUGH COLORADO OUTDOOR REGIONAL PARTNERSHIPS.

50-00656, WINOOSKI MYERS POOL RENOVATIONS, MYERS MEMORIAL PARK, CITY OF WINOOSKI- IS REQUESTING LWCF ASSISTANCE TO RENOVATED THE EXISTING POOL. THE MYERS MEMORIAL POOL WAS CONSTRUCTED IN 1972 AND OPERATED THROUGH THE END OF THE 2015 SUMMER SEASON. IN APRIL 2016, WESTON AND SAMPSON WAS AWARDED THE CONTRACT FOR THE POOL REPLACEMENT FEASIBILITY AND SCOPING STUDY AFTER A COMPETITIVE BIDDING PROCESS. THAT SAME MONTH, THEY CONDUCTED AN ASSESSMENT OF THE CURRENT FACILITY, AND PER THEIR REPORT DETERMINED THAT THE FACILITY WAS UNSAFE TO OPEN FOR THE 2016 SEASON. AS PART OF THE STUDY, WESTON AND SAMPSON MOVED ON TO WORK CLOSELY WITH THE CITY'S APPOINTED POOL FEASIBILITY AND DESIGN COMMITTEE (A GROUP OF VOLUNTEER RESIDENTS) TO ENGAGE THE COMMUNITY IN GETTING TO A CONCEPTUAL PLAN FOR A REPLACEMENT POOL FACILITY (INCLUDING A BASIC COST ESTIMATE).

50-00655,  CATAMOUNT COMMUNITY FOREST ACQUISITION, CATAMOUNT FAMILY FOREST, TOWN OF WILLISTON-REQUESTS FINANCIAL SUPPORT IN THE ACQUISITION OF 393 ACRES OF LAND FOR RECREATIONAL PURPOSES. 375.59 ACRES ARE CURRENTLY PRIVATELY OWNED AND A 17.27 ACRE PARCEL IS BEING DEEDED TO THE TOWN BY THE TRUST FOR PUBLIC LAND. THE PRIVATELY OWNED CATAMOUNT FOREST PROPERTY HAS BEEN STEADILY USED FOR RECREATIONAL PURPOSES FORTY YEARS AND THE TOWN INTENDS TO ALLOW THAT USE TO CONTINUE UNCHANGED.

50-00661, SLATE QUARRY PARK, TOWN OF POULTNEY-ON BEHALF OF TOWN OF BENNINGTON WANT ASSISTANCE TO CREATE A CURRENTLY VACANT LOT MADE UP PRIMARILY OF GRASS AND GRAVEL INTO A PASSIVE RECREATION AREA. THE 0.18 ACRE SITE WILL BE TRANSFORMED INTO A NEW PUBLIC PARK THAT HIGHLIGHTS THE HERITAGE OF THE SLATE REGION, WITH SLATE MONOLITHS AS THE FOCAL POINT. THE PARK WILL BE GRASS ON THE EASTERN AND WESTERN EDGES AND THE CENTRAL AREA WILL CONTAIN INVITING, CURVING BENCH FEATURES AND A COZY AMPHITHEATER IN THE REAR FOR PERFORMANCES AND OTHER GATHERINGS. THE SURFACE IN THE CENTRAL AREA WILL BE FLAT AND ADA-ACCESSIBLE. A SUBSURFACE OF CRUSHED SLATE (DONATED BY A LOCAL QUARRY) WILL BE PLACED UNDER ALL STRUCTURES TO PROVIDE ADEQUATE DRAINAGE AND PREVENT WATER FROM FLOWING INTO THE TOWN SEWER SYSTEM. IT WILL BE AN OASIS OF TRANQUILITY AND A BALANCE OF SLATE AND GREEN SPACE, SUN AND SHADE.

THIS NEW GRANT WILL BE UTILIZED FOR THE FOLLOWING MULTIPLE PROJECTS:  TO REFURBISH THE CURRENT TENNIS COURTS; TO CREATE A NEW HARDENED RUNNING/WALKING TRAIL AROUND THE PARK, THAT WILL ALSO BENEFIT THE CHILDREN WHO WALK TO SCHOOL WHO CURRENTLY HAVE NO OPTION BUT TO WALK ON THE SIDE OF THE ROAD; BUILD A NEW SKATE PARK; CONSTRUCT EXERCISE STATIONS WITH LANDSCAPING, BENCHES AND LIGHTING; AND, TO CRAFT OUTDOOR INSTRUMENTS CREATED BY A LOCAL ARTIST FOR CHILDREN TO EXPLORE.

THIS PROJECT INCLUDES CONSTRUCTING A NEW PLAYGROUND, CLIMBING AND FITNESS WALL AND EXERCISE STATIONS; RESURFACING AND ENLARGING BASKETBALL COURTS FOR THE PUBLIC; AND, STANDARDIZING AND REFURBISHING A SOFTBALL FIELD AND TWO MULTIPURPOSE FIELDS FOR COMMUNITY YOUTH SPORTS.

THIS GRANT WILL BE UTILIZED TO REHAB THE COMMUNITY'S OUTDOOR SWIMMING POOL. THE SHELBY SWIMMING POOL REHAB PROJECT WILL REPLACE THE CONCRETE AND METAL GUTTERS SURROUNDING THE POOL.  THEY ARE IN DISREPAIR AND UNSAFE FOR PUBLIC VISITORS UTILIZING THE POOL.  THE PROJECT WILL PROLONG THE LIFE OF THE POOL FOR THE COMMUNITY.

THIS NEW GRANT WILL BE UTILIZED TO REPLACE ALL NON-COMPLIANT ADA PLAYGROUND EQUIPMENT AT THE SCHOOL.  ADDITIONALLY, A FRENCH DRAIN SYSTEM WILL BE INSTALLED SO SNOW RUNOFF FLOODING DOESN'T IMPACT THE PLAYGROUND IN THE FUTURE.
